dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dream-like tides of shadow swirl around the wet phosphorescent streetlights that glow dimly in a desolate urban intersection.  It is Fall; the misty breath of wint rises up through the sewer grates. Huddled in a small doorway is a figure swaddled in darkne We hear footsteps, expensive shoes clicking against the pavement in a brisk city gait. The figure stirs. A well dressed man passes the doorway as the figure raise its head.  It is Kuru.  Kuru is dressed in rags, his jet black skin, including his face and bald head, is covered blue tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister? His hand reaches for the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister?  You got a dollar, mister? The man ignores him as Kuru rises behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister -- mister, please.  I'm hungry. Walking even faster, the man continues past Kuru as he strides into the street against the blinking "Don't Walk" sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister?  Mister?  Hey -- Mister! A horn explodes as a car booms past, almost hitting the m He shrieks. Kuru's laughter echoes from the dark. The man looks back but Kuru is gone.  He scurries across street toward the layered concrete parking garage. Dead red neon causes the vertical sign to read: RAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man climbs quickly, the metal stairs ringing, "thoom, thoom, thoom." As he reaches his level, a whisper floats up from the garage's concrete bowels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... mister. The man looks over the railing but sees only shadow.  He turns and pushes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grey garage is damp and cold, every sound echoing as though it were inside a whale. Nervous, the man hurries toward the only car on the level his red SAAB.  He digs out his keys and hits the remote a disarm. Far away, we hear a rattling metal sound. The man reaches the car groping for the door handle as th rattling draws closer. Hy jumps into the car, locking the door and jams the key the ignition. Suddenly, a baseball bat arcs down so that the twisting o the key seems to shatter the windshield.  The explosion o glass becomes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crash and tinkle of dirty plates being thrown into a by a busboy clearing them from the table of an old diner. Once the table is cleared by the quick automatic hands, t busboy wipes it down with a grey rag. He then places a setting.  A napkin.  A fork and a spoon. knife.  The utensils are heavy duty stainless steel.  The knife is flat like a butter knife but the end is serrated sharp enough to cut meat. We hold on the empty setting as if we were sitting at the table waiting to be served. John Bunyan throws his backpack into the booth and sits d at the empty setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I'm starving. John is a friendly looking fellow whose simple expression awe and behind-the-times wardrobe immediately places him new to the city. The waitress steps over to the table.  John smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there. She stands, pencil to pad, waiting for his order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you tonight? She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My feet hurt, my back is killing me and I smell like a hamburger.  Now what can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see here. He runs his finger down the menu, not the items, but the prices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have the hamburger special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me give you some advice, country.  When in Rome, do like the Romans, okay? She leaves. John takes out twenty dollars from a small compartment in backpack, then zips it back up. In the background, there is a commotion that swallows the normal diner noise.  John turns and we follow his gaze to far booth where a man and a woman are having an argument. Ophelia is a young, attractive woman who is uncomfortably overdressed, expecting to be in a more formal restaurant. Her date, Roman Links, has the face of a weasel.  His hai slicked back into a ponytail and he is also overdressed b quite comfortable. He holds up his hamburger to her mouth, trying to get her taste it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  You know I don't eat red meat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't fucking red!  Look at it!  It's brown.  Just try it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Links slaps the burger down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  Why go out if you never try nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call this going out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, this place ain't good enough for your highness. She tries to lower the argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck difference does it make where you eat?  All you ever want is a fucking salad.  I take you to the fucking Ritz, you'd order a fucking salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea what I want. She snatches up her purse and coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't going anywhere until you clean that plate. He snatches her by the wrist.  She struggles, then grabs fork with her free hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.  Fuck your salad. She stabs him with the fork just hard enough to make him go.  Before she can get out of the booth, he catches hold her hair, yanking her head down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You foul-mouthed bitch. He forces her face in the plate of salad and cottage chee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now eat it.  Eat it! She screams, squirming free.  Her face covered with food, eyes burning and tearing, she runs for the nearest door, women's bathroom. Links calmly pushes the last over-sized bite of burger in his mouth.  He chews, glancing around. The diner is uncomfortably quiet. He sips the last of his coffee then politely dabs at his mouth with his napkin before getting up. Links walks to the women's bathroom and lightly knocks on door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifi?  Open the door.  It's Roman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me the fuck alone. He smashes open the door, goes inside and slams it shut. John looks around the room at the frozen employees and patrons in the diner.  Muffled behind the bathroom door, sharp slap is heard and Ophelia cries out. There is another loud slap. The diner is silent, listening. John stands and slowly walks toward the bathroom as the waitress runs for the pay phone.  At the door, John can h Links talking and Ophelia crying.  He knocks. Links becomes quiet and John knocks again. The door swings open.  Links has a huge black eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard the woman crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you from another planet or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you leave her alone? Links' bony finger pokes John in the chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you do what you're supposed to do and mind your own fucking business. John shrugs, staring hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that right. Links throws the first punch but John blocks it, ramming fist into Links' gut. Links doubles over as John grabs him, spinning him out of bathroom, cocking another punch.  He swings, mashing Link thin pointy nose, sending him sailing onto his back. Links scrambles to his feet, a wild man, hair splayed acr his bleeding face, and grabs a knife from the nearest tab Screaming, he rushes at John like an animal. John jumps back but the knife slashes open his forearm. hot blood speckles the bright white ceramic floor. John howls and lunges at Links, seizing hold of the knife hand, knocking both of them to the ground.  They thrash wildly like dogs, Links even biting John, fighting for th knife until -- Ophelia stomps on Links' arm with her high heel and snatc up the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it.  Stop it, Roman! Both men recoil, standing.  Links, his ears red hot, thro back his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't over!  This ain't over! He points at his bloody nose, staring at John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never forget.  This dog's got a long memory!  And you -- He stabs a finger at Ophelia who is still holding the kni over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay for your own fucking salads! They watch as he whirls, storming out of the diner.  John suddenly conscious of his bleeding arm, groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god.  You're really hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, I think. His knees buckle a bit at the sight of so much of his own blood and he sits at one of the chrome tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not. Ophelia digs out a handful of paper napkins from a dispen and presses them to his wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe this, I mean Roman is a little crazy but what you did, it was really... thank you. John looks up into her smiling face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not from around here, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just off the bus, actually.  I didn't know it was that obvious. Ophelia looks up, suddenly uncomfortable that the eyes of diner have been on them the entire time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John.  John Bunyan. He shakes her hand, using his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ophelia.  We really need to get you to a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really have the money.  But I'll be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have someplace to stay?  Relatives? He shakes his head. Ophelia looks at the clump of napkins, white soaking red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that arm is going to get infected if we don't take care of it. She thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up outside the Mission. The Mission is an old stone building that had once been a proud, magnificent landmark.  It is now a squatting corps with its boarded windows and crumbling brick work, it wea an edifice of dark, urban decay. John follows Ophelia from the cab into the alley that run behind the Mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia pounds on the heavy steel side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It used to be something like a YMCA but it was condemned.  A man named Rex Mundi somehow convinced the city to let him run a soup kitchen out of it. She pounds on the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny?  Granny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your grandmother's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, her name is Gretchen, but she told me to call her Granny.  She's the cook. From inside, we hear a faint, old voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're closed.  Come back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny, wait.  It's Ophelia.  I have a friend here who's hurt, bleeding.  I was hoping you could... After a long pause, a series of locks and bolts click and slide before the door finally opens. Granny is a woman who looks impossibly old, thin, and wrinkled as a willow tree but has the boundless energy of child.  Her smile is a checkerboard of lost teeth gladly given for the chocolate she constantly consumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny, this is John. Her gaze fixes immediately on the cut on his arm and her bulge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, blood.  Come in.  Come in quick. She pulls them inside and the door slams shut.  We hear t locks and bolts snapping back into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining hall is a cavernous room that seems to have no walls or a ceiling, only endless rows of cheap fold out tables and chairs. Beneath nasal-humming fluorescent light, Granny sits hunc over John's arm.  Ophelia, leaning in, dabs at the wound a wet, bloody towel. Close on a large button hook as Granny pushes another sti through the flaps of skin.  She then pulls, drawing the s together. John winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost done.  There.  Just like sewing up a turkey -- She wraps it with gauze as Ophelia hands her strips of ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feels better already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just bad enough for a nice scar and a good story. She winks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, no -- Well -- An idea slips into her mind and a smile creeps across her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, how about a kiss? Ophelia laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not like that.  Just a sweet little thank you, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sure. Granny leans forward, her eyes closed, lips puckered. John puts a hand on her shoulder, leaning in, deciding to close his own eyes.  The moment is painfully slow to arri as they inch closer and closer until finally their lips touch. Granny pops back cackling with laughter.  John laughs awkwardly as she licks her lips, tasting the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, very nice.  Ophelia, you ought to give them a try. Ophelia looks up at John.  There is a hint of something beyond the smile on her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, can I get you kids something to eat, some chocolate, maybe?  Sugar for the blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, Granny, there was something else.  I brought John here because he's new to the city and has nowhere to go. Granny is suddenly very uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you'd really have to ask the boss about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Rex here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last, the fair Ophelia calls. They turn as Rex Mundi emerges from the black edges of th room. Mundi is a dark featured man, tall and sinewy who forever seems to be cast in shadow.  His clothes have an antique quality to them which includes a battered stove-pipe hat. He smiles, gliding across the room, his eyes riveted on Ophelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rex, I thought you'd gone out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me, Gretchen.  Always about. Mundi takes Ophelia's hand, holding it almost to his lips His face hovers over her, nostrils flaring, inhaling the scent of her soft skin.  Then, ever so delicately, he kis it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what do we owe this savory surprise?  Tell me, how is Ms.  Shelley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good.  I'll tell her you say hello. Mundi nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reason I'm here, Rex, is for my friend, John Bunyan.  He's looking for a job, a place to stay, anything. Ophelia gestures to John but Mundi does not look away fro her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did promise me a dishwasher, Rex. Mundi considers this, turning, appraising John.  He notic the bright, white gauze bandage and the small spot of blo seeping through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we running an animal shelter now, Gretchen?  Taking in every wounded stray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought him here, Rex.  It's my fault.  He was hurt because he helped me.  This is all I could think of. Mundi watches John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city is full of cheap hotels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have much money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why not bring him home? Ophelia doesn't know how to answer, leaving an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, it's okay.  I don't need any charity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not offering charity.  Charity has no place here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this was a soup kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh it is.  But it is not run out of charity.  There is a bargain, a contract if you will.  I offer a bowl of stew in exchange for an appetite. John is confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my mission, you see.  To teach those that will listen that no one need ever be hungry. He has a voice that seems to weave the words around his audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two percent of the world's population controls ninety percent of the world's wealth.  It sounds obscene, doesn't it?  Yet if you were to meet one of the two percenters you would find them quite at ease with it.  How do they do it? His black eyes flash like the spinning watch of a hypnoti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it that they whisper to themselves when they open a closet full of fur coats, or a garage full of sports cars?  How do they justify the consumption of so much while so many have so little?  It is painfully simple.  They may equivocate, they may obfuscate, but deep down the rich know exactly what I know.  They know that this world is cruel, it is unfair and uncaring and its single guiding principle is dog eat dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, you're as cheery as ever, Rex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should apologize for my candor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, would it be a fair question to ask you what brought you to our vanity fair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the big city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just looking for a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all?  You seek nothing but a paycheck?  You have no dreams?  No aspirations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... no.  I like to cook, I hope one day to open a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, ambition.  That is something I can understand.  Understand the dreams and you understand the man.  Would you agree with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you, Mr. Bunyan, that I am many things to many people but I am first and always a pragmatist.  My mission is growing and Gretchen reminds me that I am in need of hands.  I can offer you the bedroom above the kitchen and all of Gretchen's stew you can eat in exchange for... your hand. John is surprised by the offer, Mundi extending his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a deal. They shake left hands. Behind them, the door to the dining room opens and clangs shut.  For a moment, silhouetted against the kitchen's li we see a very large man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Kuru.  Come, someone for you to meet. Kuru moves into the room and when he reaches the light, w see that it is the man with the blue tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuru, this is John, our new hand. Kuru ignores John, whispering something in Mundi's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must be off.  Business.  Granny will show you the room, John.  Ophelia -- He tips his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is always a pleasure. Together, Kuru and Mundi leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go find you some bedding, John.  Bye now, Ophelia.  Don't be such a stranger. Ophelia and John are alone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be going too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, do you think -- I mean, would you mind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like my phone number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Very much, yes. She hands him a business card she already had in her hand It reads: Slimage Surgicenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's where I work.  I wrote my home number on the back.  Call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. He watches her leave then regards his increasingly throbb arm, the spot of blood growing wider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stands in the door frame of the small, dark room. It is bare of furniture except for a twin-sized metal fra bed and a broken chair.  A layer of dust covers the floor like moss.  A naked bulb hangs above John's head. He tugs on the pull chain but the bulb is burned out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John throws a wall switch and a buzzing strip-light flick on.  Cancerous spots of mildew grow everywhere on the dir tub, shower curtain and tile. John urinates and flushes the toilet.  Then, leaving the light on, he edges back into his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits on the bed, the metal springs shrieking beneath weight.  He takes off his shoes and lays back, pulling th single blanket over him. After a long beat, we begin to become aware of faint nois from deep within the building; pipes groaning, the distan hiss of a radiator.  It is though the building were tryin digest something. John twists, turning away from the sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crouched in the shadow behind the banister, Roman Links squats, hiding, watching Ophelia's door from the landing above.  His breathing is labored, open-mouthed as both nostrils are stuffed with wads of bloody congealing cotto Below, the lobby door opens and closes. Links presses against the spindles to watch as Ophelia cl the stairs and crosses to her apartment. Silently, he descends the stairs, creeping towards her as pulls out her keys and unlocks the door. A stair creaks. Ophelia looks back over her shoulder and sees Links.  She screams as he lunges, grabbing at her coat but she rips f of him, squeezing through her apartment door and locking behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fi!  Let me in! He pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?  What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to scare you, Fifi.  I'm really sorry about what happened. He leans against the door, mock pouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went a little crazy, that's all.  Please, Fi, open the door.  I need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to, "Buy your own fucking salads?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I love it when you use that word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Then fuck off! Ophelia feels the steel dinner knife still in her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch. She rips out the knife, holding it up as if to stab him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifi in heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifi -- Come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good poodle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty poodle. She screams, jamming the knife into the door.  An inch of blade splinters through, just missing Links' neck. Links steps back, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you leave with that guy.  I saw you take him to that flophouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  You were following me? He pulls out a small plastic folder that is labeled "Mast series 1001-2001."  Inside are five skeleton keys of whic Links draws the first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's killing me, Fi.  Just thinking about you and somebody else.  It's eating me up. She hears the first key go into the lock.  The lock jiggl as he twists it back and forth but it does not open. He rips the key out, pulls another and jams it in.  Ophel backs away as he works it against the lock. Another key is pushed in, its teeth fighting tumblers.  Ophelia yanks the knife out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you, Fifi. He slides out the last key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're mine.  My Fifi. He shoves it in, the teeth sawing into the keyhole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roman! The lock clicks and the door floats open, stopping lightl against the chain lock.  Ophelia holds her breath. After a beat, she hears his footsteps fade down the stair Ophelia leans against the door, still clutching the knife

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits up in his bed, hair heavy with sweat stuck to t side of his head.  Dehydration carries him to the plip, p plipping bathroom sink. As he rises, we see that his sheets are soaked with blood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John squints at his bleary eyed reflection, turns on the water, and reaches for a glass. The glass is knocked from the sink top and shatters on th floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh great -- John looks down and immediately sees why he broke the gla Where his hand had been is now a bloody, bandaged stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god!  My -- My hand!  Where's my hand?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His body heaving in panic, John searches frantically arou the room, under the bed, behind the radiator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?  Oh god, not my hand.  I need that! He turns for the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John finds Rex Mundi in the gleaming steel and tile kitch making himself a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rex! Mundi smiles warmly from behind a mountain of strange condiments, meats, and produce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, John.  Care to join me in a midnight snack? Mundi drags a serrated knife across a loaf of French brea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Rex.  My hand -- Look!  My hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone -- Someone stole my hand.  I woke up and it was gone! Mundi butters the two long slices of bread with clumpy wa of mayonnaise, licking his fingers, chuckling slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, John, relax.  Can't you see you're only dreaming? John stares, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Then -- then this isn't real? Mundi begins to pile things onto his sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real?  Oh no, John.  I didn't say that.  Dreams are more real, more true than life itself. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are the sum of us, John.  Secrets whispered while we slumber, revealing who we are.  And are sometimes all that we are. Mundi returns to fixing his snack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say you are missing something.  Your innocence?  Lost childhood, perhaps?  Any sexual shortcomings of late? He smiles at John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you, maybe John, run off and sold your soul to the devil? John begins to feel a sickness in his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, though, the answer is a more literal one. Mundi closes the top of his sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand which is a sandwich turns a man into a meal. He lifts the sandwich and John sees his hand between the pieces of bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Care for a bite? He takes a huge bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's eyes crack open.  He rubs his hand, then his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to counting sheep? He rolls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close as a pile of raw liver drops into a deep metal pot sizzling with onions and yellow fat. Granny stirs the reddish brown meat into the mixture, the ladles in another cup of melted fat.  As the steam blosso up, she inhales deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, still asleep, begins to smell Granny's cooking waft up through the floorboards.  The smell is suffocating, as his mouth were suddenly stuffed with liver and onions. His eyes pop open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny pours a mound of salt into her hand and begins to sprinkle it into the pot when John, stiff and disheveled, stumbles into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.  Stomach got you up, did it? Granny scoops up a big spoonful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liver and onions.  Base for any good stew.  It's real revitalizing. She offers the steaming meat to him, blowing on it betwee her teeth. John swallows hard, trying to keep his stomach from turni on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.  Not just yet. She dumps it back into the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. They both turn as the basement door slams open and Otto enters carrying a large sack of flour over his shoulder. Otto is the Mission's dwarf-like butcher.  He is a terrib wide man with enormous hands that he is constantly wiping his bloodstained apron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh John, this is Otto.  He handles the goods and deliveries and does all of our butcher work. Otto wipes his hand before they shake. He lets the bag of flour drop to the ground and crosses b to the basement door, giving John a friendly wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You butcher your own meat here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lot cheaper that way. John watches as Otto shuts the basement door behind him.  After a beat, we hear the click of a lock snapping into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is wandering outside the building, exploring his new surroundings.  It does not look quite as ominous in the sunlight. John turns, following a strange noise around back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large stray dog is chewing open some plastic garbage ba piled near a dumpster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey boy.  Find anything good? As John edges closer, the dog looks up, revealing his lar canines. John freezes as the growl grows to a bark.  The dog coils ready to attack when the back door slaps open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Otto rushes right at the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!  Go on, get! The dog whines, bolting down the alley as Otto turns to J

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You alright?  Didn't bite you, did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, mostly they're alright, even friendly considering.  But when they're hungry, you got to be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing heavy, yellow latex gloves, John scrubs the enorm silver pot Granny had been cooking in earlier.  There are stacks of soup bowls beside him, perhaps three hundred of them, already cleaned.  John rinses the pot and racks it. has been a long night. He opens the door and sees the bowl of stew Granny left f him.  It is still hot. John smells it.  It smells good.  He dips a finger into i and samples it.  Surprised, it tastes very good. He grabs one of the newly washed spoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only lit strip of fluorescent light hangs above the f table where Granny sits, smoking a cigarette. John sits down with his bowl across from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All done then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't too bad.  Those bowls were pretty clean. She smiles, nodding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They love every last drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor.  Homeless.  Rex calls them the invisible people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same people every night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we started, we had thirty to forty.  Now we get two hundred. John spoons up his first taste of the stew.  Granny watch as he blows on it and slips it into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like it? He chews a juicy piece of the meat, hot in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good.  It's really good. She seems as if she's about to start laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of meat is this?  Veal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever's donated.  Veal, chicken, beef, lamb, rabbit even. John samples it again, trying to identify the different ingredients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garlic, rosemary, basil.  Lots of pepper but -- He swishes the masticated stew over and around his tongue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I can't put my finger on. She smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else is in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a little bit of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Granny.  A secret recipe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's got a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do.  You just can't keep them to yourself. Granny stares off into the dark edges of the room, exhali cottony cloud of smoke.  John's chewing fills the silence He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember when I came to this city.  I was young and poor with little ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long time ago, Rex helped me.  Like he helped you. She smiles her checkerboard smile. John fills his spoon with a big chunk of the stringy stew meat, but stops remembering something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Granny, do you think you could loan me a quarter?  I'm good for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia, in bed, awakes and reaches to answer the ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia?  Hi, it's John. John leans against the wall, talking on an old rotary pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yeah.  We kind of met the other night... Ophelia sits up, rubbing her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over dinner. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi.  How are you?  How's your arm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  Uh, did I wake you?  I can call another time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it's okay.  You saved me again, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was -- I was having the weirdest dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, huh?  I think I'm punishing myself for not getting a chance to thank you properly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really?  I think I should be thanking you. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Then thank me by letting me cook you dinner. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds easy enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow?  Nine o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind if it's vegetarian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I forget that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow then. He lingers, savoring her goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. He hangs up, a grin spreading wide on his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We race with a pounding roar of drums, down an empty stre around a corner and into a parking lot. Faster and faster we glide across the cracked concrete wh is awash in the bright overhead kliegs toward the only ca the lot, a red Mercedes. We circle around the car, the drums at their most fevered pitch and we see the driver's door open, the window smash It hangs open, the only sound is the whining electric war that the keys have been left in the ignition.  On the car seat, we see a splintered broken gold inlay cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whine becomes the metal squeak of a broken shopping c A small figure pushes the cart which is piled high with g garbage bags down a deserted sidewalk, a cigarette hangin between her wrinkled fingers. Close on the broken wheel as blood trickles from the dark load down the chrome frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steady rhythm of droplets drip from the leaping faucet against the soft echoing digestive sounds from the buildi pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, unable to sleep, rolls up from his bed in frustrati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The refrigerator door opens, frigid light spilling into t dark kitchen. Inside, there is a massive bowl of raw meat.  John groans He turns, reaching for a cupboard but pauses when he noti the basement door is ajar. With one hand, he gently pushes and it creaks open.  Down uneven steps, he can make out a light at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto? He steps down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto, are you down here? He looks around, then starts down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the old men's locker room.  Except for a sparse few hooded electrician's lamps hung from the web of pipes overhead, it is dark. John slowly moves into the labyrinth of rusting metal lockers.  The red paint, cracked and peeling, covers the locker doors like frozen flame. He creeps down the aisles past a bank of old salvaged refrigerators and freezers most of which are wrapped and padlocked with heavy iron chains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the pegboard, behind a six foot chopping block, John s various butchering tools; hacksaws, curved bone saws, and rows of glinting, metal cleavers and paring knives. An old white radio with a bent hanger for an antenna sits a workbench beneath the peg board, its knobs crusty with smears left by bloody fiddling fingers. A layer of sawdust covers the floor, much of it clumped together with dried blood. On a coat hook, John sees Otto's apron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto? At the end of the room a dirty, clear plastic curtain han in front of what appears to be the showers. He edges toward it and slides back the curtain.  The room pitch black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, John finds the pulls chain for the naked bulb. In the center of the room, hanging from the ceiling are several blood encrusted meathooks.  Web-like cracks have formed in the large tiles and green furry mold grows in t grout lines.  Near the door, John sees a pair of black, h rubber boots. The room reeks of rot.  John catches the odor from an old metal pail and mop in the corner of the room. Grabbing hold of the wooden handle, he lifts the mop from pail, covering his nose. There is a nasty wet, sucking noise as the tangled mop strings separate from the scum at the bottom.  In the lig he sees the mop is caked with thick, red-brown gore. Sickened, he drops it back into the bucket, then turns suddenly, hearing something from the kitchen. John rushes for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John slips up from the basement. Mundi stands in the open back door, looking out, a silhou against the alley flood lights.  From outside, we hear lo animal-like growling. Mundi reaches to the counter where there is a small pile meat in unwrapped butcher brown paper.  He takes a piece red meat and tosses it outside. We hear something scarf it up as John silently backs out through the stairwell door. Mundi smiles almost imperceptibly as he tosses another ch of meat out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy.  Good boy. In the alley, we can make out the unmistakable forms of several naked men and women, hunched protectively over th meat.  As they devour it, their bare skin glows sickly un the yellow alley light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a white Persian cat, purring as it is stroked an scratched by a woman with long, red nails. Ms. Sedier is an extremely wealthy, older woman sitting alone in the clinic's waiting room.  Nestled in a chair w her mink coat over her shoulders, she seems very much lik her over-fed cat who sits in her lap. The clinic is stylishly furnished; a cross between a mode agency and a nautilus health club. Ophelia enters from her receptionist's office, smiling brightly, carrying a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're almost ready, Ms. Sedier.  I just need you to sign a few more things. She sits in the chair next to Ms. Sedier, pointing out th lines that require a signature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a beautiful cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felicity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here and here. Ms Sedier continues to sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say that animals love unconditionally.  No matter what I did or what I looked like, Felicity will always love me.  Do you have a pet, Ophelia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ms. Sedier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone should.  Do you know Mrs.  Kovit?  She has a Pekinese.  She feeds it caviar.  Can you imagine? She hands the clipboard back to Ophelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you find it funny that some pets live better than some people? Ophelia doesn't know how to answer. In the background we hear a noise coming through the wall from another room in the clinic.  It is a high-pitched wh like that of a vacuum cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think we're ready.  Would you follow me, please? She leads the older woman through a series of doors to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia opens the door allowing Ms. Sedier to enter.  Through the opening we see Shelley M. Perdue rising from desk, moving to greet Ms. Sedier. Shelley M. Perdue is a mature looking woman, unnaturally, cosmetically perfect.  Everything about her is slick with glamour magazine gloss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn, it's so good to see you again. They embrace as Ophelia is about to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ask her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ophelia, of course you know Ms.  Sedier is here for a treatment, but she's a bit nervous after the last one and she asked if it would be possible to have Felicity nearby. She is moving closer to Ophelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke with Dr. Manno and he said that it would not be a problem so would you be a dear and hold the kitty-cat?  You know I would myself if it wasn't for my allergy. Ophelia does not want to do it.  Shelley M. Perdue takes of her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't take long and I'll mind the front desk.  I really do appreciate this and so does Ms.  Sedier. She smiles, her teeth sharp and pearly white. Ophelia looks at Ms. Sedier and her cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hate to be apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Sedier is laying on the table, surrounded by several nurses and the cosmetic surgeon, all dressed in white and wearing masks. Everything in the room looks sterile and crowded with hig tech machines attached to stainless steel cables and hose Chrome-plated scalpels and other operating instruments ar spread neatly like a dinner setting. Ms. Sedier is wearing a small hospital gown that leaves h lower buttocks and legs exposed.  Her flesh is moon-white except for her face which is still covered with make-up. Ophelia, cradling the cat, watches from nearby as the operation begins. We hear again the whirring of the vacuum clearer but now is very loud. Ophelia sees the large clear container of the liposuction machine as it begins to fill with white, viscous wads of cellulite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large hunk of butter is thrown into a heavy skillet and begins to melt.  John flashes a large knife over an onion doing his best Benny Hana imitation. He carries his cutting board over to the large skillet an scrapes the various vegetables into the hot, melted butte As he turns up the burner, he looks at the clock.  It rea 7:30pm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John steps from the shower, drying himself in the swirlin steam and moves toward the sink to shave. He wipes a circle in the fogged mirror and we see his fac lathered with shaving cream.  Dragging a cheap disposable razor across his cheek, he nicks himself. Close on the blood as it trickles down the white shaving foam. He touches the blood.  There is something about it.  The redness.  Something he has never noticed before. Slowly, John brings his fingers up to his nose.  Then to tip of his tongue. He looks up at his reflection as though his name were jus called.  The steam has refogged the mirror somewhat, his image blurred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam wisps up from a rich burbling spaghetti sauce. There is a soft knock on the back door, John throws it op

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Oh no, no.  You're... perfect. She smiles from the bottom step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Everything tastes better when you're hungry. He takes her hand, leading her in and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Ophelia walk towards the far dining table. It is romantically set, including candlelight.  The candl propped up in tin cans, lean at strange angles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, this is so nice. He helps her into a chair and lifts a large jug of wine t fill their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the freshest wine for the lady. She looks at the cans and laughs, finding them terribly c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the best I could do on my budget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, no.  They're perfect.  Everything is. Close on a candlestick as it suddenly begins to collapse, though superheated, time-lapsing into a melted, multitier globular pool of slag wax. Dinner is almost over.  They are still nibbling at the ta of saucy red noodles on their plates.  The wine bottle is nearly empty and they both are feeling quite warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was little, I wanted to be a dancer.  My mother sent me to a special school one summer.  It was horrible.  The instructor would weigh us every Monday in front of the entire class.  Whoever weighted the most won the piggy prize and had to wear a little piggy nose for the rest of the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yikes.  That's pretty horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but in a way, I was grateful because I learned real quickly what dancing was all about.  It wasn't tutus and ballerina shoes.  It's a brutally competitive world where you learn to torture your body to survive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how long did that take to learn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight weeks.  One summer.  Tutu buried in the closet.  Never saw daylight again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wise woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not wise enough.  I went from wanting to be a dancer to wanting to be a model.  Not a big difference.  Took me much longer to figure that out.  After high school, I came here to the city.  I went to all the agencies.  They liked me but everyone told me I needed "work."  My nose, my chin, my breasts, my hips.  They all needed work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean surgery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  That's how I met Shelley.  I was about to get a nose job and I just broke down.  I couldn't do it.  She talked to me for a long time.  I guess she liked me 'cause she offered me a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like working there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it does feel like we're helping people.  Other times... I don't know. She drains her glass and he refills it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?  Have you always wanted to open a restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.  But I've always loved cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you are an incredible cook.  Dinner was delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, speaking of dinner, look what I found in my pocket the other day. She pulls out the knife from the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I kept it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh no.  I think my arm is having a flashback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, if what happened to you happened to me, I'd have been on the next bus back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I can't go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from this small town.  Total Hicksville.  Unless you've been there you can't imagine it.  Every day is the same.  The people are the same.  Nothing ever happens.  Living there is like being dead.  It's Night of the Living Dead, but it's night and day and night and day of the living dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't be that bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents and I never really got along.  We had a falling out when I was young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How young?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven. Ophelia laughs, almost choking on a sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found this duckling with a broken wing so I decided to bring him home and take care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was really my first pet.  I took him everywhere which was funny because I'd always see my Dad come back from hunting and he'd have all these ducks hanging upside down from his belt.  I figured that was the way you carried ducks.  So I'd loop some string around his feet and hang him from my belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't he bite you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he would just fall back and his wings would spread loose and he'd dangle there until I let him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gets worse.  We had a rule on our farm that no animal could have a name, for obvious reasons.  But that duck was my best friend.  So in secret I gave him a name.  I called him Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just a kid.  Anyway, after about a year, Jesus got nice and fat and one day when I came home from school and I smelled something cooking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  From then on I never liked school and I never trusted my parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what the worst, the weirdest part of it is?  I ate dinner that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ate poor Jesus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to.  They made me.  Even stood over me while I cleaned my plate.  But Jesus sure did taste good. She studies him with the kind of intensity that is only possible after consuming large quantities of alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to figure out why I'm so attracted to you since you don't have a hairy back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like hairy backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I hate hairy backs but I always seem to end up with men that have hairy backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about hairy palms? She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad my back isn't hairy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I. The urge to touch, to feel, to kiss is over-powering, magnetically so, pulling them up from the table to each other, their lips snapping tightly as they embrace. She tears open his buttoned shirt and reaches for his jea Every action seems to drive them farther, each desire lea to another.  He lifts her, sitting her on the table, righ where he had been eating.  He pushes her dress up past he thighs as she leans back on her hands, dizzy with alcohol We watch her reaction, lit by the flickering candles, as pulls off her underwear.  A smile creeps across her face, then a short giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feeds me, then eats me. We see them from the dark edges of the room.  Her thighs wrapped around his head when she suddenly feels a chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, wait... He looks up over her leg.  Looks around, then up at her.  They laugh guiltily as he lifts her up. We hold on the table listening to their laughter fade as run for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving down the hall towards John's door, we hear the sou of violent love making.  It sounds almost bestial. The door opens, as the sounds rise to their most desperat and wild and we see the lovers sound asleep, the sheets w about their naked intertwined bodies. But the wild animal sounds continue, as we move over the to the open window.  The sounds are coming from outside, rising up from the alley. They grow more and more vicious, until -- A scream. John lurches up. Ophelia stirs slightly, as he eases from her side and goe the window. Outside in the alley, he sees two stray dogs savagely fighting over a large bone.  White, against the dark fur the dogs, its strange shape catches John eye.  It is a bo he has never seen before. After a moment, he closes the window, shutting out the no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has begun to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia enters, closing the door behind her.  She is very disheveled, her dress not zipped all the way up, still ve tipsy and smiling.  Obviously, she had a good time. Then she hears something.  Something inside her apartment It is still and dark inside, the orange of dawn hardly visible behind the drawn blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's in here? Her heart pounds as she reaches for the nearest light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a gun. The light clicks on a metal desk lamp, and she shines it the darkness.  She lets out a scream when the improvised finds -- Roman Links, hunched strangely, standing on her futon bed He looks over his shoulder, his broken nose is taped up, eyes wide like an animal frozen in the headlights of a ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, Roman!  What --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch! He charges at her and she sees that he is naked under his long black leather coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch!  Filthy, fucking bitch! She rips the lamp from its cord, the light flashing blue it dies. As he lunges at her, she swings the lamp violently, catch him on the side of the head, knocking him over a chair. Links scurries wildly to his feet and races for the door, still screaming. She slams the door behind him and slides the heavy iron deadbolt.  She nearly crumbles with relief, but realizes something is wrong with her apartment. There is a terrible smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny stirs up a mixture of liver and onions as John ent a smile stretched from ear to ear.  His hair is pointing various gravity defying positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That smells good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a good morning to you, John. John smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your company leaving this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?  Was she all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  Wearing an equally ridiculous smile. John smiles even harder, almost blushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I'm starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worked up an appetite, did we?  Maybe you'd like a taste? She scoops up a spoonful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, I could eat anything. She offers him the steaming helping of meat and wet onion and he opens wide. It's hot and he chews carefully.  He is again surprised b the richness and flavor.  Rolling it in his mouth, the li seems to melt away, his face contorting orgasmically. Granny smiles, holding her spoon like some bizarre advertisement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background, we can hear a vigorous scrubbing sound The phone begins to ring but the scrubbing does not stop. The answering machine clicks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I woke up I was thinking maybe it was all a dream, but then I found, well not exactly a glass slipper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, on the pay phone, is holding her bright pink pantie Smiling, he smells them, as if they were a country mornin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is not your typical fairy tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia, on her hands and knees, is wearing rubber gloves scrubbing the carpet with a heavy brush and sudsy water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should scour the countryside, trying every butt, searching for the perfect fit. She drops the brush into the bucket and grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, John, I'm home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  I called work but they said you weren't coming in.  Not hungover, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.  Was it Roman? There is a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  What happened? Her voice is very faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just scared me.  When I came in he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  He did what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pissed all over my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia, just tell me where he lives --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, John.  I called the police.  They're looking for him.  I had the landlord change the locks.  I don't want it to get any worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I understand.  But if you need anything.  Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  John, I had a really beautiful time last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Sedier is again in the waiting room.  She sits awkwar as her thighs, buttocks, and abdomen are encased by heavy medical binders used to patch the liposuction punctures. There is a tension to her body as though she were afraid motion might cause some seepage, some meaty human juice t leak out of the sieve-like holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Ms. Sedier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're smiling today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I?  I guess I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a boy? Her smile brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  I remember that smile.  It feels wonderful while it lasts but that's the trouble with smiles, they never do. The smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you wish to pay for this visit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By check as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a problem with your last check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already spoken to Shelley about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something, dear?  How much do you weigh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A size seven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once weighed one hundred four pounds, wore a size four and had an eighteen inch waist just like Scarlett O'Hara. She leans back and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Manno positions Ms. Sedier's lower legs in the stirrups of the adjustable operating table. Ms. Sedier stares up past the bright lights at the mirror ceiling as the anesthetic is fed into the air mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ms. Sedier.  From one hundred.
She sucks at the gas, her thoughts drifting up to the mir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95... 90... Mirror, mirror on the wall... Outside the observation window, Ophelia pets the fat whit cat.  The sudden vacuum whir makes the cat cry out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh, it's okay. The cat continues to cry and as Dr. Manno goes to work, Felicity squirms and jumps free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felicity! She follows the darting cat who runs straight to Shelley' office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat stops, circling a pair of high heels, its white t curving up the perfect calf of Shelley Perdue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Ms. Perdue, the cat got spooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.  Come here.  Look. She is standing at the wall adjacent to the reception are The two-way mirror behind Ophelia's desk allows Shelley t look into the waiting area while maintaining the privacy her office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that him?  The one you brought to the mission? Ophelia looks out the glass and sees John talking to Mimi one of Shelley's stunning beauty technicians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's adorable. Ophelia smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is. She starts to turn for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  Watch.  I want you to see something.  Look at his eyes. Mimi smiles at John, batting her luscious false eyelashes John jokes with her, smiling boyishly. Finishing a report, she stands to return a file to an ope cabinet. The drawer is very low.  She bends.  He watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  There they are.  Eyes like that never lie. Ophelia's smile again fades away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't feel hurt, Ophelia.  Or jealous.  He is only looking at her as one might look upon a Monet, or a Michelangelo.  Beauty demands our admiration.  His eyes speak for him but you mustn't fault their honesty. She scoops up the purring cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if I were you, I would certainly ask myself, does he look at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John turns as Ophelia enters the waiting area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to take you to lunch.  I made reservations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reservations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  They do let you eat lunch, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She grabs her coat and purse while Mimi smiles at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a trendy little bistro.  A charred, pepper-crusted filet mignon is set before John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is exactly the kind of place I'd like to open one day.  Oh, that smells good, doesn't it? She nods as a walnut and avocado salad is placed in front her.  There is a clatter of wielded knives and stabbing f as John begins sawing open his meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be too big.  That's the trick.  The bigger it is, the more prep there is, the less fresh it is and the more assembly line it becomes.  You might as well open a McDonald's.  God, I'm starving. Red, ruddy juice oozes from a glistening cube of steak th he pitchforks into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lovely, John.  I've always wanted to come here but it's so expensive. He nods, his jaw grinding hard while she watches him, her fork furtively advancing on her salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get the money? Suddenly he grimaces, choking down the lump of meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a funny taste... like charcoal.  Maybe it's overcooked. He pokes at the bloody steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?  It's almost raw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be. He continues to eat but tries to cut away the charred cru slicing out the reddest part of the steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you didn't answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny gave me some money, she said she knew I'd play her back some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, she is.  And she's a helluva cook.  Her stew is amazing.  I'm trying to get the recipe.  It's unbelievably rich.  How's your salad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I know what you really want. He stabs a tiny bit of steak onto a single fork tine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, just a little taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, you know I don't eat meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  Is it a taste thing or an ethical thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethical... mostly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe those vegetables died for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do eyes have to do with life?  A blind man isn't alive?  That's not ethics.  It's just discrimination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to have a reason.  It's a personal choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know but it's not like it's the forbidden fruit here.  You won't burn in hell for it.  And one tiny teeny weeny taste won't turn you into some kind of strung out meat addict.  So come on, just try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Why do you want me to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you ever watched two people in a restaurant feeding each other, sharing their food?  I know why they do it.  It's because they're in love.  They want their lover to taste what they're tasting to feel what they're feeling.  That's all it is. Ophelia smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- She watches as he lifts the tiny, uneven cut of meat to h mouth like a bizarre communion.  She closes her eyes, her lips slowly parting as he slips the fork inside. John smiles as she chews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little party going on in there I think. Ophelia shivers, the heavy taste blooming through her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I just did that.  I must really like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, why don't we pick up some pig's feet and have a real lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I get it.  You're Satan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hate me now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.  Maybe I just need a taste, a tiny teeny weeny taste. She leans toward him and they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From far away, someone watches as they exit the restauran We hear the mucused whistle of his breathing and a sound repeats rhythmically; swick, chick... swick, chick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was wonderful.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like that. Roman Links peers around the corner of the alley, fondlin switch blade that he continues to open and close; swick, chick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crescent moon cuts scythe-like through the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is washing bowls.  The stack appears to have doubled size.  He is about to drown another beneath the sudsy wat when he notices a small puddle of stew gravy at the botto the bowl. He slips off his yellow latex glove and runs his finger a the curved belly of the bowl. Sticking the coated finger into his mouth, he sucks.  Aft moment, we hear a small crunch as he absently bites down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow -- shit. A tiny drop of blood swells around his knuckle and he suc on his finger again. Outside, one of the alley dogs begins to bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are several women in the waiting area, all of whom reading glamour magazines.  Ophelia, at her reception des is also reading a glamour magazine. The only sound in the clinic is the rattle of magazine pa being turned. Beneath her desk, Ophelia rubs her thighs together.  She a terrible itch on the inner part of each thigh. Glancing up, she surreptitiously slides her hand under he dress.  As she scratches, her nail catches on something t hurts to touch. Concerned, she goes to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in a stall, she pulls her dress up and examines her thigh.  There are several red sores swollen with irritati At the center of each sore is a white protuberance, like stye but harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelley is talking to Dr, Manno when Ophelia enters, obviously upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt, Ms. Perdue, but there's something... something wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I thought it was just a rash but it's gotten worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right.  Come.  Sit here and let's let Dr. Manno have a look. She gestures to the examination table and Ophelia sits, fitting her feet into the steel stirrups.  Swinging a lig between her legs, Dr. Manno examines the sores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow -- yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Difficult to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, please.  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calcified cellulite.  In certain cases, particularly with vegetarians, cellulite spreads beneath the derma like a spore, typically in dark, moist places like between toes or the inner thigh.  The danger is that it is impossible to know how large the tubors have gotten. He probes her flesh, feeling a large lump.  With a pair o gleaming stainless steel forceps, he clamps hold of one o the white nubs. He pulls and the nub is revealed to be a thick white stal like a root growing from the eye of a potato. Ophelia winces and writhes in the chair as Dr. Manno continues pulling the stalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming.  Hold on. The side of her thigh bulges, the root obviously connecte something much larger. Ophelia screams as the fist-like potato of calcified fat torn from her thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia continues to scream, bolting up from her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia?! Ophelia breathes, looking at John, realizing she is in he apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a dream.  Just a bad dream. She opens her leg and examines the inner thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Is something wrong with your leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what that is? There are several small dimple-like marks on her thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but it looks good to me. He starts to bite her but she pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not funny.  It's cellulite.  It means that I have a diffused pattern of irregular and disconnective tissue.  It's a genetic predisposition.  That's what's so horrible.  There are olympic athletes with cellulite.  It doesn't make any sense, why would nature design something like this, or acne, or warts.  What's the purpose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So people like Shelley Perdue could make a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Ophelia.  Maybe nature is evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know the only way to get rid of cellulite is to go U.T.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the knife.  It's done with lasers now but we still call it U.T.K. She leans back down, switching off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're right, John.  Nature is evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big stray is viciously digging at the garbage behind th mission.  Sensing someone, his head jerks up. Roman Links stops.  He looks terrible, still wearing the clothes; one brown crusty wad still plugging his nose. The dog growls.  Links growls back.  The dog coils onto i haunches, baring its teeth.  Links slides the knife out o his pocket; swick. The dog attacks and Links slashes a bright red cut across flank.  Howling, the dog scampers away.  Links smiles, wi the bloody blade on his pant leg. Prowling along the back of the Mission, Links searches fo way inside.  He finds a rotting piece of plywood covering basement window and pries it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worming through the small window, Links drops down among stalls of the men's room, the toilets are black with an unctuous grime.  He slips on a patch of congealed grease he moves through the showers into the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creeping through the maze of lockers, he finds the work bench.  Several pounds of meat and miscellaneous organs h been fed through the grinder.  Huge piles of hamburger si proportioned onto butcher paper. Sniffing, eyes wide as he reacts to every noise, Links cr toward the refrigerators. One of the chains hangs loosely around the bulbous waist an old Frigidaire.  The padlock is open. Quietly, Links pops the door.  In the white light and swirling frost, his expression turns to horror. The door slams shut, revealing Kuru. Links yelps, coiling back, his knife flashing from his pocket.  Kuru sees the tiny blade and smiles. From the back of his belt, he unsheathes his massive gurk like blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several smaller dogs now digging through the garbage reac a terrible animal-like scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia is sitting anxiously at her desk, staring into th appointment book.  There are no names scheduled after thr thirty. Ophelia begins to circle the open space, her pen orbiting only blank hole in the book.  After a moment, the circle becomes a spiral, the pen trail whirlpooling until the en space is blackened into an inky tangle. She looks over at a clock.  It is three twenty.  She is n very nervous. Glancing at the mirror that separates her from Shelley, s gets up and goes to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ophelia talks to the reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a big deal.  People change themselves every day.  It is as natural as getting a haircut.  It's more natural than having your ears pierced.  If you had a cavity, would you ignore it?  No.  You see, it's not big deal.  But if it isn't then why am I freaking out?  I don't know!  You need help -- The door opens and Shelley smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are.  Ready? Ophelia takes a breath and looks back into the mirror.  T reflection answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
